verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:6
verses.text: Let us see, therefore, whether the chief good which the philosophers mark out be such that it has reference neither to a dumb animal nor to the body, and cannot be attained without virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:7
verses.text: Aristippus, the founder of the Cyrenaic sect, who thought that bodily pleasure was the chief good, ought to be removed from the number of philosophers, and from the society of men, because he compared himself to a beast.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:8
verses.text: The chief good of Hieronymus is to be without pain, that of Diodorus to cease to be in pain.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:9
verses.text: But the other animals avoid pain; and when they are without pain, or cease to be in pain, are glad.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:10
verses.text: What distinction, then, will be given to man, if his chief good is judged to be common with the beasts? Zeno thought that the chief good was to live agreeably to nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:11
verses.text: But this definition is a general one.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:12
verses.text: For all animals live agreeably to nature, and each has its own nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:13
verses.text: Epicurus maintained that it was pleasure of the soul.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:14
verses.text: What is pleasure of the soul but joy, in which the soul for the most part luxuriates, and unbends itself either to sport or to laughter? But this good befalls even dumb animals, which, when they are satisfied with pasture, relax themselves to joy and wantonness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:15
verses.text: Dinomachus and Callipho approved of honourable pleasure; but they either said the same that Epicurus did, that bodily pleasure is dishonourable; or if they considered bodily pleasures to be partly base and partly honourable, then that is not the chief good which is ascribed to the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:16
verses.text: The Peripatetics make up the chief good of goods of the soul, and body, and fortune.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:17
verses.text: The goods of the soul may be approved of; but if they require assistance for the completion of happiness, they are plainly weak.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:18
verses.text: But the goods of the body and of fortune are not in the power of man; nor is that now the chief good which is assigned to the body, or to things placed without us, because this double good extends even to the cattle, which have need of being well, and of a due supply of food.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:19
verses.text: The Stoics are believed to have entertained much better views, who said that virtue was the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:20
verses.text: But virtue cannot be the chief good, since, if it is the endurance of evils and of labours, it is not happy of itself; but it ought to effect and produce the chief good, because it cannot be attained without the greatest difficulty and labour.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:21
verses.text: But, in truth, Aristotle wandered far from reason, who connected honour with virtue, as though it were possible for virtue at any time to be separated from honour, or to be united with baseness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:22
verses.text: Herillus the Pyrrhonist made knowledge the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:23
verses.text: This indeed belongs to man, and to the soul only, but it may happen to him without virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:24
verses.text: For he is not to be considered happy who has either learnt anything by hearing, or has gained the knowledge of it by a little reading; nor is it a definition of the chief good, because there may be a knowledge either of bad things, or at any rate of things that are useless.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:25
verses.text: And if it is the knowledge of good and useful things which you have acquired by labour, nevertheless it is not the chief good, because knowledge is not sought on its own account, but on account of something else.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:26
verses.text: For the arts are learnt on this account, that they may be to us the means of gaining support, or a source of glory, or even of pleasure; and it is plain that these things cannot be the chief goods.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:27
verses.text: Therefore the philosophers do not observe the rule even in moral philosophy, inasmuch as they are at variance with one another on the main point itself, that is, in that discussion by which the life is moulded.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 29:28
verses.text: For the precepts cannot be equal, or resembling one another, when some train men to pleasure, others to honour, others indeed to nature, others to knowledge; some to the pursuit, others to the avoiding of riches; some to entire insensibility to pain, others to the endurance of evils: in all which, as I have shown before, they turn aside from reason, because they are ignorant of God.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:2
verses.text: XXXIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:3
verses.text: —That Men are Born to Justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:4
verses.text: Let us now see what is proposed to the wise man as the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:5
verses.text: That men are born to justice is not only taught by the sacred writings, but is sometimes acknowledged even by these same philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:6
verses.text: Thus Cicero says: "But of all things which fall under the discussion of learned men, nothing assuredly is more excellent than that it should be clearly understood that we are born to justice".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:7
verses.text: This is most true.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:8
verses.text: For we are not born to wickedness, since we are a social and sociable animal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:9
verses.text: The wild beasts are produced to exercise their fierceness; for they are unable to live in any other way than by prey and bloodshed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:10
verses.text: These, however, although pressed by extreme hunger, nevertheless refrain from animals of their own kind.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:11
verses.text: Birds also do the same, which must feed upon the carcases of others.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:12
verses.text: How much more is it befitting, that man, who is united with man both in the interchange of language and in communion of feeling, should spare man, and love him! For this is justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:13
verses.text: But since wisdom has been given to man alone, that he may understand God, and this alone makes the difference between man and the dumb animals, justice itself is bound up in two duties.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:14
verses.text: He owes the one to God as to a father, the other to man as to a brother; for we are produced by the same God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:15
verses.text: Therefore it has been deservedly and rightly said, that wisdom is the knowledge of divine and human affairs.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:16
verses.text: For it is right that we should know what we owe to God, and what to man; namely, to God religion, to man affection.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:17
verses.text: But the former belongs to wisdom, the latter to virtue; and justice comprises both.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:18
verses.text: If, therefore, it is evident that man is born to justice, it is necessary that the just man should be subject to evils, that he may exercise the virtue with which he is endued.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:19
verses.text: For virtue is the enduring of evils.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:20
verses.text: He will avoid pleasures as an evil: he will despise riches, because they are frail; and if he has them, he will liberally bestow them, to preserve the wretched: he will not be desirous of honours, because they are short and transitory; he will do injury to no one; if he shall suffer, he will not retaliate; and he will not take vengeance upon one who plunders his property.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:21
verses.text: For he will deem it unlawful to injure a man; and if there shall be any one who would compel him to depart from God, he will not refuse tortures nor death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 30:22
verses.text: Thus it will come to pass, that he must necessarily live in poverty and lowliness, and in insults, or even tortures.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:2
verses.text: XXXV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:3
verses.text: —That Immortality is the Chief Good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:4
verses.text: What, then, will be the advantage of justice and virtue, if they shall have nothing but evil in life? But if virtue, which despises all earthly goods, most wisely endures all evils, and endures death itself in the discharge of duty, cannot be without a reward, what remains but that immortality alone is its reward? For if a happy life falls to the lot of man, as the philosophers will have it, and in this point alone they do not disagree, therefore also immortality falls to him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:5
verses.text: For that only is happy which is incorruptible; that only is incorruptible which is eternal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:6
verses.text: Therefore immortality is the chief good, because it belongs both to man, and to the soul, and to virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:7
verses.text: We are only directed to this; we are born to the attainment of this.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:8
verses.text: Therefore God proposes to us virtue and justice, that we may obtain that eternal reward for our labours.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:9
verses.text: But concerning that immortality itself we will speak in the proper place.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:10
verses.text: There remains the philosophy of Logic, which contributes nothing to a happy life.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:11
verses.text: For wisdom does not consist in the arrangement of speech, but in the heart and the feeling.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 31:12
verses.text: But if natural philosophy is superfluous, and this of logic, and the philosophers have erred in moral philosophy, which alone is necessary, because they have been unable in any way to find out the chief good; therefore all philosophy is found to be empty and useless, which was unable to comprehend the nature of man, or to fulfil its duty and office.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:2
verses.text: XXXVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:3
verses.text: —Of the Philosophers,—Namely, Epicurus and Pythagoras.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:4
verses.text: Since I have spoken briefly of philosophy, now also I will speak a few things about the philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:5
verses.text: This is especially the doctrine of Epicurus, that there is no providence.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:6
verses.text: And at the same time he does not deny the existence of gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:7
verses.text: In both respects he acts contrary to reason.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:8
verses.text: For if there are gods, it follows that there is a providence.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:9
verses.text: For otherwise we can form no intelligible idea of God, for it is His peculiar province to foresee.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:10
verses.text: But Epicurus says He takes no care about anything.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:11
verses.text: Therefore He disregards not only the affairs of men, but also heavenly things.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:12
verses.text: How, therefore, or from what, do you affirm that He exists? For when you have taken away the divine providence and care, it would naturally follow that you should altogether deny the existence of God; whereas now you have left Him in name, but in reality you have taken Him away.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:13
verses.text: Whence, then, did the world derive its origin, if God takes no care of anything? There are, he says, minute atoms, which can neither be seen nor touched, and from the fortuitous meeting of these all things arose, and are continually arising.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:14
verses.text: If they are neither seen nor perceived by any part of the body, how could you know of their existence? In the next place, if they exist, with what mind do they meet together to effect anything? If they are smooth, they cannot cohere: if they are hooked and angular, then they are divisible; for hooks and angles project, and can be cut off.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:15
verses.text: But these things are senseless and unprofitable.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:16
verses.text: Why should I mention that he also makes souls capable of extinction? who is refuted not only by all philosophers and general persuasion, but also by the answers of bards, by the predictions of the Sibyls, and lastly, by the divine voices of the prophets themselves; so that it is wonderful that Epicurus alone existed, who should place the condition of man on a level with the flocks and beasts.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:17
verses.text: What of Pythagoras, who was first called a philosopher, who judged that souls were indeed immortal, but that they passed into other bodies, either of cattle, or of birds, or of beasts? Would it not have been better that they should be destroyed, together with their bodies, than thus to be condemned to pass into the bodies of other animals? Would it not be better not to exist at all, than, after having had the form of a man, to live as a swine or a dog? And the foolish man, to gain credit for his saying, said that he himself had been Euphorbus in the Trojan war, and that, when he had been slain, he passed into other figures of animals, and at last became Pythagoras.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 32:18
verses.text: O happy man! to whom alone so great a memory was given; or rather unhappy, who, when changed into a sheep, was not permitted to be ignorant of what he was! And would to Heaven that he alone had been thus senseless! He found also some to believe him, and some indeed among the learned, to whom the inheritance of folly passed.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:2
verses.text: XXXVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:3
verses.text: —Of Socrates and His Contradiction.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:4
verses.text: After him Socrates held the first place in philosophy, who was pronounced most wise even by the oracle, because he confessed that he knew one thing only,—namely, that he knew nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:5
verses.text: And on the authority of this oracle it was right that the natural philosophers should restrain themselves, lest they should either inquire into those things which they could not know, or should think that they knew things which they did not know.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:6
verses.text: Let us, however, see whether Socrates was most wise, as the Pythian god proclaimed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:7
verses.text: He often made use of this proverb, that that which is above us has also no reference to us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:8
verses.text: He has now passed beyond the limits of his opinion.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:9
verses.text: For he who said that he knew one thing only, found another thing to speak of, as though he knew it; but that in vain.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:10
verses.text: For God, who is plainly above us, is to be sought for; and religion is to be undertaken, which alone separates us from the brutes, which indeed Socrates not only rejected, but even derided, in swearing by a goose and a dog, as if in truth he could not have sworn by aesculapius, to whom he had vowed a cock.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:11
verses.text: Behold the sacrifice of a wise man! And because he was unable to offer this in his own person, since he was at the point of death, he entreated his friends to perform the vow after his death, lest forsooth he should be detained as a debtor in the lower regions.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 33:12
verses.text: He assuredly both pronounced that he knew nothing, and made good his statement.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:2
verses.text: XXXVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:3
verses.text: —Of Plato, Whose Doctrine Approaches More Nearly to the Truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:4
verses.text: His disciple Plato, whom Tully speaks of as the god of philosophers, alone of all so studied philosophy that he approached nearer to the truth; and yet, because he was ignorant of God, he so failed in many things, that no one fell into worse errors, especially because in his books respecting the state he wished all things to be common to all.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:5
verses.text: This is endurable concerning property, though it is unjust.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:6
verses.text: For it ought not to be an injury to any one, if he possesses more than another through his own industry; or to be a profit to any one, if through his own fault he possesses less.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:7
verses.text: But, as I have said, this is capable of being endured in some way.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:8
verses.text: Shall there be a community of wives also, and of children? Shall there be no distinction of blood, or certainty of race? Shall there be neither families, nor relationships, nor affinities, but all things confused and indiscriminate, as in herds of cattle? Shall there be no self-restraint in men, no chastity in women? What conjugal affection can there be in these, between whom on either side there is no sure or peculiar love? Who will he dutiful towards a father, when he knows not from whom he was born? Who will love a son, whom he will reckon as not his own? Moreover, he opened the senate house to women, and entrusted to them warfare, magistracies, and commands.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:9
verses.text: But how great will be the calamity of that city, in which women shall discharge the duties of men! But of this more fully at another opportunity.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:10
verses.text: Zeno, the master of the Stoics, who praises virtue, judged that pity, which is a very great virtue, should be cut away, as though it were a disease of the mind, whereas it is at the same time dear to God and necessary for men.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:11
verses.text: For who is there who, when placed in any evil, would be unwilling to be pitied, and would not desire the assistance of those who might succour them, which is not called forth so as to render aid, except by the feeling of pity? Although he calls this humanity and piety, he does not change the matter itself, only the name.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:12
verses.text: This is the affection which has been given to man alone, that by mutual assistance we might alleviate our weakness; and he who removes this affection reduces us to the life of the beasts.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:13
verses.text: For his assertion that all faults are equal, proceeds from that inhumanity with which also be assails pity as a disease.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:14
verses.text: For he who makes no difference in faults, either thinks that light offences ought to be visited with severe punishments, which is the part of a cruel judge, or that great offences should be visited with slight punishments, which is the part of a worthless judge.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:15
verses.text: In either case there is injury to the state.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 34:16
verses.text: For if the greatest crimes are lightly punished, the boldness of the wicked will increase, and go on to deeds of greater daring; and if a punishment of too great severity is inflicted for slight offences, inasmuch as no one can be exempt from fault, many citizens will incur peril, who by correction might become better.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:2
verses.text: XXXIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:3
verses.text: —Of Various Philosophers, and of the Antipodes.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:4
verses.text: These things, truly, are of small importance, but they arise from the same falsehood.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:5
verses.text: Xenophanes said that the orb of the moon is eighteen times larger than this earth of ours; and that within its compass is contained another earth, which is inhabited by men and animals of every kind.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:6
verses.text: About the antipodes also one can neither hear nor speak without laughter.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:7
verses.text: It is asserted as something serious, that we should believe that there are men who have their feet opposite to ours.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:8
verses.text: The ravings of Anaxagoras are more tolerable, who said that snow was black.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:9
verses.text: And not only the sayings, but the deeds, of some are ridiculous.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:10
verses.text: Democritus neglected his land which was left to him by his father, and suffered it to become a public pasture.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:11
verses.text: Diogenes with his company of dogs, who professes that great and perfect virtue in the contempt of all things, preferred to beg for his support, rather than to seek it by honest labour, or to have any property.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:12
verses.text: Undoubtedly the life of a wise man ought to be to others an example of living.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:13
verses.text: If all should imitate the wisdom of these, how will states exist? But perhaps the same Cynics were able to afford an example of modesty, who lived with their wives in public.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:14
verses.text: I know not how they could defend virtue, who took away modesty.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:15
verses.text: Nor was Aristippus better than these, who, I believe, that he might please his mistress Lais, instituted the Cyrenaic system, by which he placed the end of the chief good in bodily pleasure, that authority might not be wanting to his faults, or learning to his vices.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:16
verses.text: Are those men of greater fortitude to be more approved, who, that they might be said to have despised death, died by their own hands? Zeno, Empedocles, Chrysippus, Cleanthes, Democritus, and Cato, imitating these, did not know that he who put himself to death is guilty of murder, according to the divine right and law.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:17
verses.text: For it was God who placed us in this abode of flesh: it was He who gave us the temporary habitation of the body, that we should inhabit it as long as He pleased.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:18
verses.text: Therefore it is to be considered impious, to wish to depart from it without the command of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:19
verses.text: Therefore violence must not be applied to nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:20
verses.text: He knows how to destroy His own work.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:21
verses.text: And if any one shall apply impious hands to that work, and shall tear asunder the bonds of the divine workmanship, he endeavours to flee from God, whose sentence no one will be able to escape, whether alive or dead.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 35:22
verses.text: Therefore they are accursed and impious, whom I have mentioned above, who even taught what are the befitting reasons for voluntary death; so that it was not enough of guilt that they were self-murderers, unless they instructed others also to this wickedness.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:2
verses.text: XL.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:3
verses.text: —Of the Foolishness of the Philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:4
verses.text: There are innumerable sayings and doings of the philosophers, by which their foolishness may be shown.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:5
verses.text: Therefore, since we are unable to enumerate them all, a few will be sufficient.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:6
verses.text: It is enough that it is understood that the philosophers were neither teachers of justice, of which they were ignorant, nor of virtue, of which they falsely boast.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:7
verses.text: For what can they teach, who often confess their own ignorance? I omit to mention Socrates, whose opinion is well known.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:8
verses.text: Anaxagoras proclaims that all things are over-spread with darkness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:9
verses.text: Empedocles says that the paths for finding out the truth of the senses are narrow.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:10
verses.text: Democritus asserts that truth lies sunk in a deep well; and because they nowhere find it, they therefore affirm that no wise man has as yet existed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 36:11
verses.text: Since, therefore, human wisdom has no existence (Socrates says in the writings of Plato), let us follow that which is divine, and let us give thanks to God, who has revealed and delivered it to us; and let us congratulate ourselves, that through the divine bounty we possess the truth and wisdom, which, though sought by so many intellects through so many ages, philosophy was not able to discover.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:2
verses.text: XLI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:3
verses.text: —Of True Religion and Wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:4
verses.text: Now, since we have refuted false religion, which is in the worship of the gods, and false wisdom, which is in the philosophers, let us come to true religion and wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:5
verses.text: And, indeed, we must speak of them both conjointly, because they are closely connected.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:6
verses.text: For to worship the true God, that and nothing else is wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:7
verses.text: For that God who is supreme and the Maker of all things, who made man as the image of Himself, on this account conferred on him alone of all animals the gift of reason, that he might pay back honour to Him as his Father and his Lord, and by the exercise of this piety and obedience might gain the reward of immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:8
verses.text: This is a true and divine mystery.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:9
verses.text: But among those, because they are not true, there is no agreement.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:10
verses.text: Neither are sacred rites performed in philosophy, nor is philosophy treated of in sacred things; and on this account their religion is false, because it does not possess wisdom; and on this account their wisdom is false, because it does not possess religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 37:11
verses.text: But where both are joined together, there the truth must necessarily be; so that if it is asked what the truth itself is, it may be rightly said to be either wise religion or religious wisdom.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:2
verses.text: XLII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:3
verses.text: —Of Religious Wisdom: the Name of Christ Known to None, Except Himself and His Father.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:4
verses.text: I will now say what wise religion, or religious wisdom, is.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:5
verses.text: God, in the beginning, before He made the world, from the fountain of His own eternity, and from the divine and everlasting Spirit, begat for Himself a Son incorruptible, faithful, corresponding to His Father's excellence and majesty.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:6
verses.text: He is virtue, He is reason, He is the word of God, He is wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:7
verses.text: With this artificer, as Hermes says, and counsellor, as the Sibyl says, He contrived the excellent and wondrous fabric of this world.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:8
verses.text: In fine, of all the angels, whom the same God formed from His own breath, He alone was admitted into a participation of His supreme power, He alone was called God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:9
verses.text: For all things were through Him, and nothing was without Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:10
verses.text: In fine, Plato, not altogether as a philosopher, but as a seer, spoke concerning the first and second God, perhaps following Trismegistus in this, whose words I have translated from the Greek, and subjoined: "The Lord and Maker of all things, whom we have thought to be called God, created a second God, who is visible and sensible.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:11
verses.text: But by sensible I mean, not that He Himself receives sensation, but that He causes sensation and sight.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:12
verses.text: When, therefore, He had made this, the first, and one, and only one, He appeared to Him most excellent, and full of all good qualities".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:13
verses.text: The Sibyl also says that God the guide of all was made by God, and another, that  "God the Son of God must be known,"    as those examples which I have brought forward in my books declare.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:14
verses.text: Him the prophets, filled with the inspiration of the Divine Spirit, proclaimed; of whom especially Solomon in the book of Wisdom, and also his father, the writer of divine hymns—both most renowned kings, who preceded the times of the Trojan war by a hundred and eighty years—testify that He was born of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:15
verses.text: His name is known to none, except to Himself and the Father, as John teaches in the Revelation.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:16
verses.text: Hermes says that His name cannot be uttered by mortal mouth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:17
verses.text: Yet by men He is called by two names—Jesus, which is Saviour, and Christ, which is King.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:18
verses.text: He is called Saviour on this account, because He is the health and safety of all who believe in God through Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 38:19
verses.text: He is called Christ on this account, because He Himself will come from heaven at the end of this dispensation to judge the world, and, having raised the dead, to establish for Himself an everlasting kingdom.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:2
verses.text: XLIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:3
verses.text: —Of the Name of Jesus Christ, and His Twofold Nativity.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:4
verses.text: But lest by any chance there should be any doubt in your mind why we call Him Jesus Christ, who was born of God before the world, and who was born of man three hundred years ago, I will briefly explain to you the reason.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:5
verses.text: The same person is the son of God and of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:6
verses.text: For He was twice born: first of God, in the spirit, before the origin of the world; afterwards in the flesh of man, in the reign of Augustus; and in connection with this fact is an illustrious and great mystery, in which is contained both the salvation of men and the religion of the Supreme God, and all truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:7
verses.text: For when first the accursed and impious worship of gods crept in through the treachery of the demons, then the religion of God remained with the Hebrews alone, who, not by any law, but after the manner of their fathers, observed the worship handed down to them by successive generations, even until the time when they went forth out of Egypt under the leadership of Moses, the first of all the prophets, through whom the law was given to them from God; and they were afterwards called Jews.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:8
verses.text: Therefore they served God, being bound by the chains of the law.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:9
verses.text: But they also, by degrees going astray to profane rites, undertook the worship of strange gods, and, leaving the worship of their father, sacrificed to senseless images.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:10
verses.text: Therefore God sent to them prophets filled with the Divine Spirit, to upbraid them with their sins and proclaim repentance, to threaten them with the vengeance which would follow, and announce that it would come to pass, if they persisted in the same faults, that He would send another as the bearer of a new law; and having removed the ungrateful people from their inheritance, He would assemble to Himself a more faithful people from foreign nations.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:11
verses.text: But they not only persisted in their course, but even slew the messengers themselves.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:12
verses.text: Therefore He condemned them on account of these deeds: nor did He any longer send messengers to a stubborn people; but He sent His own Son, to call all nations to the favour of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:13
verses.text: Nor, however, did He shut them out, impious and ungrateful as they were, from the hope of salvation: but He sent Him to them before all others, that if they should by chance obey, they might not lose that which they had received; but if they should refuse to receive their God, then, the heirs being removed, the Gentiles would come into possession.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:14
verses.text: Therefore the supreme Father ordered Him to descend to the earth, and to put on a human body, that, being subject to the sufferings of the flesh, He might teach virtue and patience not only by words, but also by deeds.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 39:15
verses.text: Therefore He was born a second time as man, of a virgin, without a father, that, as in His first spiritual birth, being born of God alone, He was made a sacred spirit, so in His second and fleshly birth, being born of a mother only, He might become holy flesh, that through Him the flesh, which had become subject to sin, might be freed from destruction.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:2
verses.text: XLIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:3
verses.text: —The Twofold Nativity of Christ is Proved from the Prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:4
verses.text: That these things should thus take place as I have set them forth, the prophets had before predicted.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:5
verses.text: In the writings of Solomon it is thus written: "The womb of a virgin was strengthened, and conceived: and a virgin was impregned, and became a mother in great pity".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:6
verses.text: In Isaiah it is thus written: "Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and ye shall call His name Immanuel;" which, being interpreted, is God with us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:7
verses.text: For He was with us on the earth, when He assumed flesh; and He was no less God in man, and man in God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:8
verses.text: That He was both God and man was declared before by the prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:9
verses.text: That He was God, Isaiah thus declares: "They shall fall down unto Thee, they shall make supplication unto Thee; since God is in Thee, and we knew it not, even the God of Israel.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:10
verses.text: They shall be ashamed and confounded, all of them who oppose themselves to Thee, and shall go to confusion".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:11
verses.text: Also Jeremiah: "This is our God, and there shall none other be compared unto Him; He hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob His servant, and to Israel His beloved.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:12
verses.text: Afterward He was seen upon earth, and dwelt among men".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:13
verses.text: Likewise that He was man, the same Jeremiah says: "And He is man, and who knew Him?" Isaiah also thus speaks: "And the Lord shall send them a man who shall save them, and with judgment shall He heal them".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:14
verses.text: Also Moses himself in the book of Numbers: "There shall come a star out of Jacob, and a man shall arise out of Israel".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 40:15
verses.text: For this cause, therefore, being God, He took upon Him flesh, that, becoming a mediator between God and man, having overcome death, He might by His guidance lead man to God.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:2
verses.text: XLV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:3
verses.text: —The Power and Works of Christ are Proved from the Scriptures.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:4
verses.text: We have spoken of His nativity; now let us speak of His power and works, which, when He wrought them among men, the Jews, seeing them to be great and wonderful, supposed that they were done by the influence of magic, not knowing that all those things which were done by Him had been foretold by the prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:5
verses.text: He gave strength to the sick, and to those languishing under various diseases, not by any healing remedy, but instantaneously, by the force and power of His word; He restored the weak, He made the lame to walk, He gave sight to the blind, He made the dumb to speak, the deaf to hear; He cleansed the polluted and unclean, He restored their right mind to those who were maddened with the attack of demons, He recalled to life and light those who were dead or now buried.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:6
verses.text: He also fed and satisfied five thousand men with five loaves and two fishes.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:7
verses.text: He also walked upon the sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:8
verses.text: He also in a tempest commanded the wind to be still, and immediately there was a calm; all which things we find predicted both in the books of the prophets and in the verses of the Sibyls.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:9
verses.text: When a great multitude resorted to Him on account of these miracles, and, as He truly was, believed Him to be the Son of God, and sent from God, the priests and rulers of the Jews, filled with envy, and at the same time excited with anger, because He reproved their sins and injustice, conspired to put Him to death; and that this would happen, Solomon had foretold a little more than a thousand years before, in the book of Wisdom, using these words: "Let us defraud the righteous, for he is unpleasant to us, and upbraideth us with our offences against the law.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:10
verses.text: He maketh his boast that he has the knowledge of God, and he calleth himself the Son of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:11
verses.text: He is made to reprove our thoughts: it grieveth us even to look upon him; for his life is not like the life of others, his ways are of another fashion.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:12
verses.text: We are counted by him as triflers; he withdraweth himself from our ways, as from filthiness; he commendeth greatly the latter end of the just, and boasteth that he has God for his father.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:13
verses.text: Let us see, therefore, if his words be true; let us prove what end he shall have; let us examine him with rebukes and torments, that we may know his meekness and prove his patience; let us condemn him to a shameful death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:14
verses.text: Such things have they imagined, and have gone astray; for their own folly hath blinded them, and they do not understand the mysteries of God".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:15
verses.text: Therefore, being unmindful of these writings which they read, they incited the people as though against an impious man, so that they seized and led Him to trial, and with impious words demanded His death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:16
verses.text: But they alleged against Him as a crime this very thing, that He said that He was the Son of God, and that by healing on the Sabbath He broke the law, which He said that He did not break, but fulfilled.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:17
verses.text: And when Pontius Pilate, who then as legate had authority in Syria, perceived that the cause did not belong to the office of the Roman judge, he sent Him to Herod the Tetrarch, and permitted the Jews themselves to be the judges of their own law: who, having received the power of punishing His guilt, sentenced Him to the cross, but first scourged and struck him with their hands, put on Him a crown of thorns, spat upon His face, gave Him gall and vinegar to eat and drink; and amidst these things no word was heard to fall from His lips.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:18
verses.text: Then the executioners, having cast lots over His tunic and mantle, suspended Him on the cross, and affixed Him to it, though on the next day they were about to celebrate the Passover, that is, their festival.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 41:19
verses.text: Which crime was followed by prodigies, that they might understand the impiety which they had committed; for at the same moment in which He expired, there was a great earthquake, and a withdrawing of the sun, so that the day was turned into night.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:2
verses.text: XLVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:3
verses.text: —It is Proved from the Prophets that the Passion and Death of Christ Had Been Foretold.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:4
verses.text: And the prophets had predicted that all these things would thus come to pass.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:5
verses.text: Isaiah thus speaks: "I am not rebellious, nor do I oppose: I gave my back to the scourge, and my cheeks to the hand: I turned not away my face from the foulness of spitting".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:6
verses.text: The same prophet says respecting His silence: "I was brought as a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb before its shearers is dumb, so He opened not His mouth".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:7
verses.text: David also, in the xxxivth Psalm: "The abjects were gathered together against me, and they knew me not: they were scattered, yet felt no remorse: they tempted me, and gnashed upon me with their teeth".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:8
verses.text: The same also says respecting food and drink in the lxviiith Psalm: "They gave me also gall for my meat, and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:9
verses.text: Also respecting the cross of Christ: "And they pierced my hands and my feet, they numbered all my bones: they themselves have looked and stared upon me; they parted my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:10
verses.text: Moses also says in Deuteronomy: " And thy life shall hang in doubt before thine eyes, and thou shall fear day and night, and shall have none assurance of thy life".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:11
verses.text: Also in Numbers: "God is not in doubt as a man, nor does He suffer threats as the son of man".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:12
verses.text: Also Zechariah says: "And they shall look on me whom they pierced".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:13
verses.text: Amos thus speaks of the obscuring of the sun: "In that day, saith the Lord, the sun shall go down at noon, and the clear day shall be dark; and I will turn your feasts into mourning, and your songs into lamentation".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:14
verses.text: Jeremiah also speaks of the city of Jerusalem, in which He suffered: "Her sun is gone down while it was yet day; she hath been confounded and reviled, and the residue of them will I deliver to the sword".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:15
verses.text: Nor were these things spoken in vain.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:16
verses.text: For after a short time the Emperor Vespasian subdued the Jews, and laid waste their lands with the sword and fire, besieged and reduced them by famine, overthrew Jerusalem, led the captives in triumph, and prohibited the others who were left from ever returning to their native land.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:17
verses.text: And these things were done by God on account of that crucifixion of Christ, as He before declared this to Solomon in their Scriptures, saying, "And Israel shall be for perdition and a reproach to the people, and this house shall be desolate; and every one that shall pass by shall be astonished, and shall say, Why hath God done these evils to this land, and to this house? And they shall say, Because they forsook the Lord their God, and persecuted their King, who was dearly beloved by God, and crucified Him with great degradation, therefore hath God brought upon them these evils".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 42:18
verses.text: For what would they not deserve who put to death their Lord, who had come for their salvation?.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:2
verses.text: XLVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:3
verses.text: —Of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ, the Sending of the Apostles, and the Ascension of the Saviour into Heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:4
verses.text: After these things they took His body down from the cross, and buried it in a tomb.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:5
verses.text: But on the third day, before daybreak, there was an earthquake, and the stone with which they had closed the sepulchre was removed, and He arose.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:6
verses.text: But nothing was found in the sepulchre except the clothes in which the body had been wrapped.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:7
verses.text: But that He would rise again on the third day, the prophets had long ago foretold.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:8
verses.text: David, in the xvth Psalm: "Thou wilt not leave my soul in hell, neither wilt Thou suffer Thine Holy One to see corruption".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:9
verses.text: Likewise Hosea: This my Son is wise, therefore He shall not stay long in the anguish of His sons: and I will ransom Him from the hand of the grave.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:10
verses.text: Where is thy judgment, O death, where is thy sting? "The same again says: "After two days He will revive us on the third day".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:11
verses.text: Therefore, after His resurrection He went into Galilee, and again assembled His disciples, who had fled through fear; and having given them commands which He wished to be observed, and having arranged for the preaching of the Gospel throughout the whole world, He breathed into them the Holy Spirit, and gave them the power of working miracles, that they might act for the welfare of men as well by deeds as words; and then at length, on the fortieth day, He returned to His Father, being carried up into a cloud.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:12
verses.text: The prophet Daniel had long before shown this, saying, "I saw in the night vision, and, behold, one like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven, and came to the Ancient of days; and they who stood beside Him brought Him near before Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:13
verses.text: And there was given Him a kingdom, and glory, and dominion, and all people, tribes, and languages shall serve Him; and His power is an everlasting one, which shall not pass away, and His kingdom that which shall not be destroyed".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 43:14
verses.text: Also David in the cixth Psalm: "The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou at my right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:2
verses.text: XLVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:3
verses.text: —Of the Disinheriting of the Jews, and the Adoption of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:4
verses.text: Since, therefore, He sits at the right hand of God, about to tread down His enemies, who tortured Him, when He shall come to judge the world, it is evident that no hope remains to the Jews, unless, turning themselves to repentance, and being cleansed from the blood with which they polluted themselves, they shall begin to hope in Him whom they denied.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:5
verses.text: Therefore Esdras thus speaks: "This passover is our Saviour and our refuge.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:6
verses.text: Consider and let it come into your heart, that we have to abase Him in a figure: and after these things we have hoped in Him".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:7
verses.text: Now that the Jews were disinherited, because they rejected Christ, and that we, who are of the Gentiles, were adopted into their place, is proved by the Scriptures.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:8
verses.text: Jeremiah thus speaks: "I have forsaken mine house, I have given mine heritage into the hands of her enemies.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:9
verses.text: Mine heritage is become unto me as a lion in the forest; it hath given forth its voice against me: therefore have I hated it".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:10
verses.text: Also Malachi: "I have no pleasure in you, saith the Lord, neither will I accept an offering at your hand.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:11
verses.text: For from the rising of the sun even unto the going down thereof, my name shall be great among the Gentiles".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:12
verses.text: Isaiah also thus speaks: "I come to gather all nations and tongues: and they shall come and see my glory".

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 44:13
verses.text: The same says in another place, speaking in the person of the Father to the Son: "I the Lord have called Thee in righteousness, and will hold Thine hand, and will keep Thee, and give Thee for a covenant of my people, for a light of the Gentiles; to open the eyes of the blind, to bring out the prisoners from the prison, and them that sit in darkness out of the prison-house".

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:2
verses.text: XLIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:3
verses.text: —That God is One Only.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:4
verses.text: If therefore the Jews have been rejected by God, as the faith due to the sacred writings shows, and the Gentiles, as we see, brought in, and freed from the darkness of this present life and from the chains of demons, it follows that no other hope is proposed to man, unless he shall follow true religion and true wisdom, which is in Christ, and he who is ignorant of Him is always estranged from the truth and from God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:5
verses.text: Nor let the Jews, or philosophers, flatter themselves respecting the Supreme God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:6
verses.text: He who has not acknowledged the Son has been unable to acknowledge the Father.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:7
verses.text: This is wisdom, and this is the mystery of the Supreme God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:8
verses.text: God willed that He should be acknowledged and worshipped through Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:9
verses.text: On this account He sent the prophets beforehand to announce His coming, that when the things which had been foretold were fulfilled in Him, then He might be believed by men to be both the Son of God and God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:10
verses.text: Nor, however, must the opinion be entertained that there are two Gods, for the Father and the Son are one.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:11
verses.text: For since the Father loves the Son, and gives all things to Him, and the Son faithfully obeys the Father, and wills nothing except that which the Father does, it is plain that so close a relationship cannot be separated, so that they should be said to be two in whom there is but one substance, and will, and faith.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:12
verses.text: Therefore the Son is through the Father, and the Father through the Son.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:13
verses.text: One honour is to be given to both, as to one God, and is to be so divided through the worship of the two, that the division itself may be bound by an inseparable bond of union.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 45:14
verses.text: He will leave nothing to himself, who separates either the Father from the Son, or the Son from the Father.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:2
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:3
verses.text: —Why God Assumed a Mortal Body, and Suffered Death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:4
verses.text: It remains to answer those also, who deem that it was unbecoming and unreasonable that God should be clothed with a mortal body; that He should be in subjection to men; that He should endure insults; that He should even suffer tortures and death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:5
verses.text: I will speak my sentiments, and I will sum up, as I shall be able, an immense subject in few words.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:6
verses.text: He who teaches anything, ought, as I think, himself to practice what he teaches, that he may compel men to obey.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:7
verses.text: For if he shall not practice them, he will detract from the faith due to his precepts.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:8
verses.text: Therefore there is need of examples, that the precepts which are given may have firmness, and if any one shall prove contumacious, and shall say that they cannot be carried out in practice, the instructor may refute him by actual fact.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:9
verses.text: Therefore a system of teaching cannot be perfect, when it is delivered by words only; but it then becomes perfect, when it is completed by deeds.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:10
verses.text: Since therefore Christ was sent to men as a teacher of virtue, for the perfection of His teaching it was plainly befitting that He should act as well as teach.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:11
verses.text: But if He had not assumed a human body, He would not have been able to practice what He taught,—that is, not to be angry, not to desire riches, not to be inflamed with lust, not to fear pain, to despise death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:12
verses.text: These things are plainly virtues, but they cannot be done without flesh.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 46:13
verses.text: Therefore He assumed a body on this account, that, since He taught that the desires of the flesh must be overcome, He might in person first practice it, that no one might allege the frailty of the flesh as an excuse.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:2
verses.text: LI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:3
verses.text: —Of the Death of Christ on the Cross.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:4
verses.text: I will now speak of the mystery of the cross, lest any one should happen to say, If death must be endured by Him, it should have been not one that was manifestly infamous and dishonourable, but one which had some honour.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:5
verses.text: I know, indeed, that many, while they dislike the name of the cross, shrink from the truth, though there is in it great reasonableness and power.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:6
verses.text: For since He was sent for this purpose, that He might open to the lowest men the way to salvation, He made Himself humble that He might free them.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:7
verses.text: Therefore He underwent that kind of death which is usually inflicted on the humble, that an opportunity of imitation might be given to all.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:8
verses.text: Moreover, since He was about to rise again, it was not allowable that His body should be in any way mutilated, or a bone broken, which happens to those who are beheaded.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:9
verses.text: Therefore the cross was preferred, which reserved the body with the bones uninjured for the resurrection.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:10
verses.text: To these grounds it was also added, that having undertaken to suffer and to die, it was befitting that He should be lifted up.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:11
verses.text: Thus the cross exalted Him both in fact and in emblem, so that His majesty and power became known to all, together with His passion.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:12
verses.text: For in that He extended His hands on the cross, He plainly stretched out His wings towards the east and the west, under which all nations from either side of the world might assemble and repose.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:13
verses.text: But of what great weight this sign is, and what power it has, is evident, since all the host of demons is expelled and put to flight by this sign.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:14
verses.text: And as He Himself before His passion put to confusion demons by His word and command, so now, by the name and sign of the same passion, unclean spirits, having insinuated themselves into the bodies of men, are driven out, when racked and tormented, and confessing themselves to be demons, they yield themselves to God, who harasses them.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 47:15
verses.text: What therefore can the Greeks expect from their superstitions and with their wisdom, when they see that their gods, whom they do not deny to be demons also, are subdued by men through the cross?.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:2
verses.text: LII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:3
verses.text: —The Hope of the Salvation of Men Consists in the Knowledge of the True God, and of the Hatred of the Heathens Against the Christians.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:4
verses.text: There is therefore but one hope of life for men, one harbour of safety, one refuge of liberty, if, laying aside the errors by which they were held, they open the eyes of their mind and recognise God, in whom alone is the abode of truth; despise earthly things, and those made from the ground esteem as nothing philosophy, which is foolishness with God; and having undertaken true wisdom, that is, religion, become heirs of immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:5
verses.text: But indeed they are not so much opposed to the truth as to their own safety; and when they hear these things, they abominate them as some inexpiable wickedness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:6
verses.text: But they do not even endure to hear: they think that their ears are polluted with impiety if they hear; nor do they now refrain from reproaches, but assail them with the most insulting words; and also, if they have obtained the power, persecute them as public enemies, yea, even as worse than enemies; for enemies, when they have been vanquished, are punished with death or slavery; nor is there any torturing after the laying down of arms, although those deserved to suffer all things who wished so to act, that piety might have place among swords.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:7
verses.text: Cruelty, combined with innocence, is unheard of, nor is it worthy of the condition of victorious enemies.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:8
verses.text: What is the so powerful cause of this fury? Doubtless, because they cannot contend on the ground of reason, they urge forward their cause by means of violence; and, with the subject not understood, they condemn those as most pernicious persons who have declined to make a stand respecting the fact of their innocence.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:9
verses.text: Nor do they deem it sufficient that those whom they unreasonably hate should die by a speedy and simple death; but they lacerate them with refined tortures, that they may satisfy their hatred, which is not produced by any fault, but by the truth, which is hateful to those who live wickedly, because they take it ill that there are some whom their deeds cannot please.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 48:10
verses.text: They desire in every way to destroy these, that they may be able to sin without restraint in the absence of any witness.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:2
verses.text: LIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:3
verses.text: —The Reasons of the Hatred Against the Christians are Examined and Refuted.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:4
verses.text: But they say that they do these things for the defence of their gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:5
verses.text: In the first place, if they are gods, and have any power and influence, they have no need of the defence and protection of men, but they manifestly defend themselves.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:6
verses.text: Or how is man able to hope for aid from them, if they are unable to average even their own injuries? Therefore it is a vain and foolish thing to wish to be avengers of the gods, except that their distrust is more apparent from this.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:7
verses.text: For he who undertakes the protection of the god whom he worships, admits the worthlessness of that god; but if he worships him on this account, because he thinks him powerful, he ought not to wish to defend him, by whom he himself ought to be defended.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:8
verses.text: We therefore act rightly.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:9
verses.text: For when those defenders of false gods, who are rebellious against the true God, persecute His name in us, we resist not either in deed or in word, but with meekness, and silence, and patience, we endure whatever cruelty is able to contrive against us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:10
verses.text: For we have confidence in God, from whom we expect that retribution will hereafter follow.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:11
verses.text: Nor is this confidence ungrounded, since we have in some cases heard, and in other cases seen, the miserable ends of all those who have dared to commit this crime.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:12
verses.text: Nor has any one had it in his power to insult God with impunity; but he who has been unwilling to learn by word has learned by his own punishment who is the true God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:13
verses.text: I should wish to know, when they compel men to sacrifice against their will, what reasoning they have with themselves, or to whom they make that offering.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:14
verses.text: If it is made to the gods, that is not worship, nor an acceptable sacrifice, which is made by those who are displeasing to them, which is extorted by injury, which is enforced by pain.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:15
verses.text: But if it is done to those whom they compel, it is plainly not a benefit, which any one would not receive, he even prefers rather to die.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:16
verses.text: If it is a good to which you call me, why do you invite me with evil? why with blows, and not with words? why not by argument, but by bodily tortures? Whence it is manifest that that is an evil, to which you do not allure me willing, but drag me refusing.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:17
verses.text: What folly is it to wish to consult the good of any one against his will! If any one, under the pressure of evils, attempts to have recourse to death, can you, if you either wrest the sword from his hand, or cut the halter, or drag him away from the precipice, or pour out the poison, boast yourself as the preserver of the man, when he, whom you think that you have preserved, does not thank you, and thinks that you have acted ill towards him, in averting from him the death which be desired, and in not permitting him to reach the end and rest from his labours? For a benefit ought not to be weighed according to the quality of the action, but according to the feelings of him who receives it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:18
verses.text: Why should you reckon as a benefit that which is an injury to me? Do you wish me to worship your gods, which I consider deadly to myself? If it is a good, I do not envy it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:19
verses.text: Enjoy your good by yourself.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:20
verses.text: There is no reason why you should wish to succour my error, which I have undertaken by my judgment and inclination.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:21
verses.text: If it is evil, why do you drag me to a participation in evil? Use your own fortune.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 49:22
verses.text: I prefer to die in the practice of that which is good, than to live in evil.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:2
verses.text: LIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:3
verses.text: —Of the Freedom of Religion in the Worship of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:4
verses.text: These things may indeed be said with justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:5
verses.text: But who will hear, when men of furious and unbridled spirit think that their authority is diminished if there is any freedom in the affairs of men? But it is religion alone in which freedom has placed its dwelling.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:6
verses.text: For it is a matter which is voluntary above all others, nor can necessity be imposed upon any, so as to worship that which he does not wish to worship.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:7
verses.text: Some one may perhaps pretend, he cannot wish it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:8
verses.text: In short, some, through fear of torments, or overcome by tortures, have assented to detestable sacrifices: they never do that voluntarily which they did from necessity; but when the opportunity is again given to them, and liberty restored, they again betake themselves to God, and appease Him with prayers and tears, repenting not of the will, which they had not, but of the necessity which they endured; and pardon is not denied to those who make satisfaction.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:9
verses.text: What then does he accomplish who pollutes the body, since he cannot change the will?
