But, in fact, men of weak understanding, if they have induced any man of spirit to sacrifice to their gods, with incredible alacrity insolently exult, and rejoice, as though they had sent an enemy under the yoke.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:10
verses.text: But if any one, neither frightened by threats nor by tortures, shall have chosen to prefer his faith to his life, cruelty puts forth all its ingenuity against him, plans dreadful and intolerable things; and because they know that death for the cause of God is glorious, and that this is a victory on our side, if, having overcome the torturers, we lay down our life in behalf of the faith and religion, they also themselves strive to conquer us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:11
verses.text: They do not put us to death, but they search out new and unheard-of tortures, that the frailty of the flesh may yield to pains, and if it does not yield, they put off further punishment, and apply diligent care to the wounds, that while the scars are yet fresh, a repetition of the torture may inflict more pain; and while they practice this torture upon the innocent, they evidently consider themselves pious, and just, and religious (for they are delighted with such sacrifices to their gods), but they term the others impious and desperate.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 50:12
verses.text: What perversity is this, that he who is punished, though innocent, should be called desperate and impious, and that the torturer, on the other hand, should be called just and pious!.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:2
verses.text: LV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:3
verses.text: —The Heathens Charge Justice with Impiety in Following God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:4
verses.text: But they say that those are rightly and deservedly punished, who dislike the public rites of religion handed down to them by their ancestors.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:5
verses.text: What if those ancestors were foolish in undertaking vain religious rites, as we have shown before, shall we be prohibited from following true and better things? Why do we deprive ourselves of liberty, and become enslaved to the errors of others, as though bound to them? Let it be permitted us to be wise, let it be permitted us to inquire into the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:6
verses.text: But, however, if it pleases them to defend the folly of their ancestors, why are the Egyptians suffered to escape, who worship cattle and beasts of every kind as deities? Why are the gods themselves made the subjects of comic representations? and why is he honoured who derides them most wittily? Why are philosophers attended to, who either say that there are no gods, or that, if there are any, they take no interest in, and do not regard the affairs of men, or argue that there is no providence at all, which rules the world?  But they alone of all are judged impious who follow God and the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:7
verses.text: And since this is at once justice, and wisdom, they lay to its charge either impiety or folly, and do not perceive what it is which deceives them, when they call evil good, and good evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:8
verses.text: Many indeed of the philosophers, and especially Plato and Aristotle, spoke many things about justice, asserting and extolling that virtue with the greatest praise, because it gives to each its due, because it maintains equity in all things; and whereas the other virtues are as it were silent, and shut up within, that it is justice alone which is neither concerned for itself only, nor hidden, but altogether shows itself abroad, and is ready for conferring a benefit, so as to assist as many as possible: as though in truth justice ought to be in judges only, and those placed in any post of authority, and not in all men.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:9
verses.text: And yet there is no one of men, not even of the lowest and of beggars, who is not capable of justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:10
verses.text: But because they did not know what it was, from what source it proceeded, and what was its mode of operation, they assigned to a few only that highest virtue, that is, the common good of all, and said that it aimed at no advantages peculiar to itself, but only the interests of others.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 51:11
verses.text: And not without reason was Carneades raised up, a man of the greatest talent and penetration, to refute their speech, and overthrow the justice, which had no firm foundation; not because he thought that justice was to be blamed, but that he might show that its defenders brought forward no firm or certain argument respecting justice.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:2
verses.text: LVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:3
verses.text: —Of Justice, Which is the Worship of the True God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:4
verses.text: For if justice is the worship of the true God (for what is so just with respect to equity, so pious with respect to honour, so necessary with respect to safety, as to acknowledge God as a parent, to reverence Him as Lord, and to obey His law or precepts?), it follows that the philosophers were ignorant of justice, for they neither acknowledged God Himself, nor observed His worship and law; and on this account they might have been refuted by Carneades, whose disputation was to this effect, that there is no natural justice, and therefore that all animals defended their own interests by the guidance of nature itself, and therefore that justice, if it promotes the advantages of others and neglects its own, is to be called foolishness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:5
verses.text: But if all people who are possessed of power, and the Romans themselves, who are masters of the whole world, were willing to follow justice, and to restore to every one his property which they have seized by force and arms, they will return to cottages and a condition of want.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:6
verses.text: And if they did this, they might indeed be just, but they must of necessity be considered foolish, who proceed to injure themselves for the advantage of others.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:7
verses.text: Then, if any one should find a man who was through a mistake offering for sale gold as mountain-brass, or silver as lead, and necessity should compel him to buy it, will he conceal his knowledge and buy it for a small sum, or will he rather inform the seller of its value? If he shall inform him, he will manifestly be called just; but he will also be foolish, for conferring an advantage upon another, and injuring himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:8
verses.text: But it is easy to judge in a case of injury.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:9
verses.text: What if he shall incur danger of his life, so that it shall be necessary for him either to kill another or to die, what will he do? It may happen that, having suffered shipwreck, he may find some feeble person clinging to a plank; or, his army having been defeated, in his flight he may find a wounded man on horseback: will he thrust the one from the plank, the other from his horse, that he himself may be able to escape? If he shall wish to be just, he will not do it; but he will also be judged foolish, who in sparing the life of another shall lose his own.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 52:10
verses.text: If he shall do it, he will indeed appear wise, because he will provide for his own interests; but he will also be wicked, because he will commit a wrong.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:2
verses.text: LVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:3
verses.text: —Of Wisdom and Foolishness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:4
verses.text: These things indeed are said with acuteness; but we are able very readily to reply to them.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:5
verses.text: For the imitation of names causes it thus to appear.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:6
verses.text: For justice bears a resemblance to foolishness, and yet it is not foolishness; and at the same time malice bears a resemblance to wisdom, and yet it is not wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:7
verses.text: But as that malice is intelligent and shrewd in preserving its own interests, it is not wisdom, but cunning and craftiness; so likewise justice ought not to be called foolishness, but innocence, because the just man must be wise, and the foolish man unjust.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:8
verses.text: For neither reason nor nature itself permits that he who is just should not be wise, since it is plain that the just man does nothing except that which is right and good, and always avoids that which is perverted and evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:9
verses.text: But who will be able to distinguish between good and evil, depravity and rectitude, but he who shall be wise? But the fool acts badly, because he is ignorant of what is good and evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:10
verses.text: Therefore he does wrong, because he is unable to distinguish between things which are perverted and those which are right.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:11
verses.text: Therefore justice cannot be befitting to the foolish man, nor wisdom to the unjust.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:12
verses.text: He is not then a foolish person who has not thrust off a shipwrecked man from a plank, nor a wounded man from his horse, because he has abstained from injury, which is a sin; and it is the part of the wise man to avoid sin.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:13
verses.text: But that he should appear foolish at first sight is caused by this, that they suppose the soul to be extinguished together with the body; and for this reason they refer all advantage to this life.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:14
verses.text: For if there is no existence after death, it is plain that he acts foolishly who spares the life of another to his own loss, or who consults the gain of another more than his own.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:15
verses.text: If death destroys the soul, we must use our endeavours to live for a longer time, and more to our own advantage; but if there remains after death a life of immortality and blessedness, the just and wise man will certainly despise this corporeal existence, with all earthly goods, because he will know what kind of a reward he is about to receive from God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:16
verses.text: Therefore let us maintain innocency, let us maintain justice, let us undergo the appearance of foolishness, that we may be able to maintain true wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:17
verses.text: And if it appears to men senseless and foolish to prefer torture and death rather than to sacrifice to gods, and to escape without harm, let us however strive to exhibit faithfulness towards God by all virtue and by all patience.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:18
verses.text: Let not death terrify us, nor pain subdue us, so as to prevent the vigour of our mind and constancy from being preserved unshaken.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:19
verses.text: Let them call us foolish, whilst they themselves are most foolish, and blind and dull, and like sheep; who do not understand that it is a deadly thing to leave the living God, and prostrate themselves in the adoration of earthly objects; who do not know that eternal punishment awaits those who have worshipped senseless images; and that those who have neither refused tortures nor death for the worship and honour of the true God will obtain eternal life.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:20
verses.text: This is the highest faith; this is true wisdom; this is perfect justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:21
verses.text: It matters nothing to us what fools may judge, what trifling men may think.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 53:22
verses.text: We ought to await the judgment of God, that we may hereafter judge those who have passed judgment on us.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:2
verses.text: LVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:3
verses.text: —Of the True Worship of God, and Sacrifice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:4
verses.text: I have spoken of justice, what was its nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:5
verses.text: It follows that I show what is true sacrifice to God, what is the most just manner of worshipping Him, lest any one should think that victims, or odours, or precious gifts, are desired by God, who, if He is not subject to hunger, and thirst, and cold, and desire of all earthly things, does not therefore make use of all these things which are presented in temples and to gods of earth; but as corporeal offerings are necessary for corporeal beings, so manifestly an incorporeal sacrifice is necessary for an incorporeal being.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:6
verses.text: But God has no need of those things which He has given to man for his use, since all the earth is under His power: He needs not a temple, since the world is His dwelling; He needs not an image, since He is incomprehensible both to the eyes and to the mind; He needs not earthly lights, for He was able to kindle the light of the sun, with the other stars, for the use of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:7
verses.text: What then does God require from man but worship of the mind, which is pure and holy? For those things which are made by the hands, or are outside of man, are senseless, frail, and displeasing.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:8
verses.text: This is true sacrifice, which is brought forth not from the chest but from the heart; not that which is offered by the hand, but by the mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:9
verses.text: This is the acceptable victim, which the mind sacrifices of itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:10
verses.text: For what do victims bestow? What does incense? What do garments? What does silver? What gold? What precious stones,—if there is not a pure mind on the part of the worshipper? Therefore it is justice only which God requires.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 54:11
verses.text: In this is sacrifice; in this the worship of God, respecting which I must now speak, and show in what works justice must necessarily be contained.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:2
verses.text: LIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:3
verses.text: —Of the Ways of Life, and the First Times of the World.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:4
verses.text: That there are two ways of human life was unknown neither to philosophers nor to poets, but both introduced them in a different manner.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:5
verses.text: The philosophers wished the one to be the way of industry, the other of idleness; but in this respect they were less correct in their statements, that they referred them to the advantages of this life only.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:6
verses.text: The poets spoke better who said that one of them was the way of the just, the other of the unjust; but they err in this, that they say that they are not in this life, but in the shades below.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:7
verses.text: We manifestly speak more correctly, who say that the one is the way of life, the other that of death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:8
verses.text: And here, however, we say that there are two ways; but the one on the right hand, in which the just walk, does not lead to Elysium, but to heaven, for they become immortal; the other on the left leads to Tartarus, for the unjust are sentenced to eternal tortures.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:9
verses.text: Therefore the way of justice, which leads to life, is to be held by us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:10
verses.text: Now the first duty of justice is to acknowledge God as a parent, and to fear Him as a master, to love Him as a father.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:11
verses.text: For the same Being who begat us, who animated us with vital breath, who nourishes and preserves us, has over us, not only as a father but also as a master, authority to correct us, and the power of life and death; wherefore twofold honour is due to Him from man, that is, love combined with fear.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:12
verses.text: The second duty of justice is to acknowledge man as a brother.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:13
verses.text: For if the same God made us, and produced all men on equal terms to justice and eternal life, it is manifest that we are united by the relationship of brotherhood; and he who does not acknowledge this is unjust.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:14
verses.text: But the origin of this evil, by which the mutual society of men, by which the bond of relationship has been torn asunder, arises from ignorance of the true God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:15
verses.text: For he who is ignorant of that fountain of bounty can by no means be good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:16
verses.text: Hence it is that, from the time when a multitude of gods began to be consecrated and worshipped by men, justice, as the poets relate, being put to flight, every compact was destroyed, the fellowship of human justice was destroyed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:17
verses.text: Then every one, consulting his own interest, reckoned might to be right, injured another, attacked by frauds, deceived by treachery, increased his own advantages by the inconvenience of others, did not spare relatives, or children, or parents, prepared poisoned cups for the destruction of men, beset the ways with the sword, infested the seas, gave the rein to his lust, wherever passion led him,—in short, esteemed nothing sacred which his dreadful desire did not violate.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:18
verses.text: When these things were done, then men instituted laws for themselves to promote the public advantage, that they might meanwhile protect themselves from injuries.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:19
verses.text: But the fear of laws did not suppress crimes, but it checked licentiousness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:20
verses.text: For laws were able to punish offences, they were unable to punish the conscience.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:21
verses.text: Therefore the things which before were done openly began to be done secretly.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:22
verses.text: Justice also was evaded by stealth, since they who themselves presided over the administration of the laws, corrupted by, gifts and rewards, made a traffic of their sentences, either to the escape of the evil or to the destruction of the good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 55:23
verses.text: To these things were added dissensions, and wars, and mutual depredations; and the laws being crushed, the power of acting with violence was assumed without restraint.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:2
verses.text: LX.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:3
verses.text: —Of the Duties of Justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:4
verses.text: When the affairs of men were in this condition, God pitied us, revealed and displayed Himself to us, that in Himself we might learn religion, faith, purity, and mercy; that having laid aside the error of our former life, together with God Himself we might know ourselves, whom impiety had disunited from Him, and we might choose the divine law, which unites human affairs with heavenly, the Lord Himself delivering it to us; by which law all the errors with which we have been ensnared, together with vain and impious superstitions, might be taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:5
verses.text: What we owe to man, therefore, is prescribed by that same divine law which teaches that whatever you render to man is rendered to God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:6
verses.text: But the root of justice, and the entire foundation of equity, is that you should not do that which you would be unwilling to suffer, but should measure the feelings of another by your own.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:7
verses.text: If it is an unpleasant thing to bear an injury, and he who has done it appears unjust, transfer to the person of another that which you feel respecting yourself, and to your own person that which you judge respecting another, and you will understand that you act as unjustly if you injure another as another would if he should injure you.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:8
verses.text: If we consider these things, we shall maintain innocence, in which the first step of justice is, as it were, contained.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:9
verses.text: For the first thing is, not to injure; the next is, to be of service.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 56:10
verses.text: And as in uncultivated lands, before you begin to sow, the fields must be cleansed by tearing up the thorns and cutting off all the roots of trunks, so vices must first be thrust out from our souls, and then at length virtues must be implanted, from which the fruits of immortality, being engendered by the word of God, may spring up.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:2
verses.text: LXI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:3
verses.text: —Of the Passions.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:4
verses.text: There are three passions, or, so to speak, three furies, which excite such great perturbations in the souls of men, and sometimes compel them to offend in such a manner, as to permit them to have regard neither for their reputation nor for their personal safety: these are anger, which desires vengeance; love of gain, which longs for riches; lust, which seeks for pleasures.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:5
verses.text: We must above all things resist these vices: these trunks must be rooted up, that virtues may be implanted.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:6
verses.text: The Stoics are of opinion that these passions must be cut off; the Peripatetics think that they must be restrained.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:7
verses.text: Neither of them judge rightly, because they cannot entirely be taken away, since they are implanted by nature, and have a sure and great influence; nor can they be diminished, since, if they are evil, we ought to be without them, even though restrained and used with moderation; if they are good, we ought to use them in their completeness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:8
verses.text: But we say that they ought not to be taken away nor lessened.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:9
verses.text: For they are not evil of themselves, since God has reasonably implanted them in us; but inasmuch as they are plainly good by nature,—for they are given us for the protection of life,—they become evil by their evil use.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:10
verses.text: And as bravery, if you fight in defence of your country, is a good, if against your country, is an evil, so the passions, if you employ them to good purposes, will be virtues, if to evil uses, they will be called vices.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:11
verses.text: Anger therefore has been given by God for the restraining of offences, that is, for controlling the discipline of subjects, that fear may suppress licentiousness and restrain audacity.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:12
verses.text: But they who are ignorant of its limits are angry with their equals, or even with their superiors.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:13
verses.text: Hence they rush to deeds of cruelty, hence they rise to slaughters, hence to wars.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:14
verses.text: The love of gain also has been given that we may desire and seek for the necessaries of life.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:15
verses.text: But they who are unacquainted with its boundaries strive insatiably to heap up riches.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:16
verses.text: Hence poisoning, hence defraudings, hence false wills, hence all kinds of frauds have burst forth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:17
verses.text: Moreover, the passion of lust is implanted and innate in us for the procreation of children; but they who do not fix its limits in the mind use it for pleasure only.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:18
verses.text: Thence arise unlawful loves, thence adulteries and debaucheries, thence all kinds of corruption.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 57:19
verses.text: These passions, therefore, must be kept within their boundaries and directed into their right course, in which, even though they should be vehement, they cannot incur blame.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:2
verses.text: LXII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:3
verses.text: —Of Restraining the Pleasures of the Senses.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:4
verses.text: Anger is to be restrained when we suffer an injury, that the evil may be suppressed which is imminent from a contest, and that we may retain two of the greatest virtues, harmlessness and patience.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:5
verses.text: Let the desire of gain be broken when we have that which is enough.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:6
verses.text: For what madness is it to labour in heaping up those things which must pass to others, either by robbery, or theft, or by proscription, or by death? Let lust not go beyond the marriage-bed, but be subservient to the procreation of children.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:7
verses.text: For a too great eagerness for pleasure both produces danger and generates disgrace, and that which is especially to be avoided, leads to eternal death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:8
verses.text: Nothing is so hateful to God as an unchaste mind and an impure soul.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:9
verses.text: Nor let any one think that he must abstain from this pleasure only, quae capitur ex foeminei corporis copulatione, but also from the other pleasures which arise from the rest of the senses, because they also are of themselves vicious, and it is the part of the same virtue to despise them.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:10
verses.text: The pleasure of the eyes is derived from the beauty of objects, that of the ears from harmonious and pleasant sounds, that of the nostrils from pleasant odour, that of taste from sweet food,—all of which virtue ought strongly to resist, lest, ensnared by these attractions, the soul should be depressed from heavenly to earthly things, from things eternal to things temporal, from life immortal to perpetual punishment.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:11
verses.text: In pleasures of the taste and smell there is this danger, that they are able to draw us to luxury.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:12
verses.text: For he who shall be given up to these things, either will have no property, or, if he shall have any, he will expend it, and afterwards live a life to be abominated.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:13
verses.text: But he who is carried away by hearing (to say nothing respecting songs, which often so charm the inmost senses that they even disturb with madness a settled state of the mind by certain elaborately composed speeches and harmonious poems, or skilful disputations) is easily led aside to impious worship.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:14
verses.text: Hence it is that they who are either themselves eloquent, or prefer to read eloquent writings, do not readily believe the sacred writings, because they appear unpolished; they do not seek things that are true, but things that are pleasant; nay, to them those things appear to be most true which soothe the ears.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:15
verses.text: Thus they reject the truth, while they are captivated by the sweetness of the discourse.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:16
verses.text: But the pleasure which has reference to the sight is manifold.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 58:17
verses.text: For that which is derived from the beauty of precious objects excites avarice, which ought to be far removed from a wise and just man; but that which is received from the appearance of woman hurries a man to another pleasure, of which we have already spoken above.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:2
verses.text: LXIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:3
verses.text: —That Shows are Most Powerful to Corrupt the Minds.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:4
verses.text: It remains to speak of public shows, which, since they have a more powerful influence on the corruption of the mind, ought to be avoided by the wise, and to be altogether guarded against, because it is said that they were instituted in celebration of the honours of the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:5
verses.text: For the exhibitions of shows are festivals of Saturnus.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:6
verses.text: The stage belongs to Father Liber; but the Circensian games are supposed to be dedicated to Neptunus: so that now he who takes part in these shows appears to have left the worship of God, and to have passed over to profane rites.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:7
verses.text: But I prefer to speak of the matter itself rather than of its origin.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:8
verses.text: What is so dreadful, what so foul, as the slaughter of man? Therefore our life is protected by the most severe laws; therefore wars are detestable.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:9
verses.text: Yet custom finds how a man may commit homicide without war, and without laws; and this is a pleasure to him, that he has avenged guilt.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:10
verses.text: But if to be present at homicide implies a consciousness of guilt, and the spectator is involved in the same guilt as the perpetrator, then in these slaughters of gladiators, he who is a spectator is no less sprinkled with blood than he who sheds it; nor can he be free from the guilt of bloodshed who wished it to be poured out, or appear not to have slain, who both favoured the slayer and asked a reward for him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:11
verses.text: What of the stage? Is it more holy,—on which comedy converses on the subject of debaucheries and amours, tragedy of incest and parricide? The immodest gestures also of players, with which they imitate disreputable women, teach the lusts, which they express by dancing.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:12
verses.text: For the pantomime is a school of corruption, in which things which are shameful are acted by a figurative representation, that the things which are true may be done without shame.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:13
verses.text: These spectacles are viewed by youths, whose dangerous age, which ought to be curbed and governed, is trained by these representations to vices and sins.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:14
verses.text: The circus, in truth, is considered more innocent, but there is greater madness in this, since the minds of the spectators are transported with such great madness, that they not only break out into revilings, but often rise to strifes, and battles, and contentions.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:15
verses.text: Therefore all shows are to be avoided, that we may be able to maintain a tranquil state of mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 59:16
verses.text: We must renounce hurtful pleasures, lest, charmed by pestilential sweetness, we fall into the snares of death.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:2
verses.text: LXIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:3
verses.text: —The Passions are to Be Subdued, and We Must Abstain from Forbidden Things.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:4
verses.text: Let virtue alone please us, whose reward is immortal when it has conquered pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:5
verses.text: But when the passions have been overcome and pleasures subdued labour in suppressing other things is easy to him who is a follower of God and of truth: he will never revile, who shall hope for a blessing from God; he will not commit perjury, lest he should mock God; but he will not even swear, lest at any time, either by necessity or through habit, he should fall into perjury.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:6
verses.text: He will speak nothing deceitfully, nothing with dissimulation; he will not refuse that which he has promised, nor will he promise that which he is unable to perform; he will envy no one, since he is content with himself and with his own possessions; nor will he take away from, or wish ill to another, upon whom, perhaps, the benefits of God are more plenteously bestowed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:7
verses.text: He will not steal, nor will he covet anything at all belonging to another.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:8
verses.text: He will not give his money to usury, for that is to seek after gain from the evils of others; nor, however, will he refuse to lend, if necessity shall compel any one to borrow.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:9
verses.text: He must not be harsh towards a son, nor towards a slave: he must remember that he himself has a Father and a Master.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:10
verses.text: He will so act towards these as he will wish that others should act towards him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:11
verses.text: He will not receive excessive gifts from those who have less resources than himself; for it is not just that the estates of the wealthy should be increased by the losses of the wretched.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:12
verses.text: It is an old precept not to kill, which ought not to be taken in this light, as though we are commanded to abstain only from homicide, which is punished even by public laws.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:13
verses.text: But by the intervention of this command, it will not be permitted us to apply peril of death by word, nor to put to death or expose an infant, nor to condemn one's self by a voluntary death.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:14
verses.text: We are likewise commanded not to commit adultery; but by this precept we are not only prohibited from polluting the marriage of another, which is condemned even by the common law of nations, but even to abstain from those who prostitute their persons.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:15
verses.text: For the law of God is above all laws; it forbids even those things which are esteemed lawful, that it may fulfil justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:16
verses.text: It is a part of the same law not to utter false witness, and this also itself has a wider meaning.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:17
verses.text: For if false witness by falsehood is injurious to him against whom it is spoken, and deceives him in whose presence it is spoken, we must therefore never speak falsely, because falsehood always deceives or injures.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:18
verses.text: Therefore he is not a just man who, even without inflicting injury, speaks in idle discourse.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:19
verses.text: Nor indeed is it lawful for him to flatter, for flattery is pernicious and deceitful; but he will everywhere guard the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 60:20
verses.text: And although this may for the present be unpleasant, nevertheless, when its advantage and usefulness shall appear, it will not produce hatred, as the poet says, but gratitude.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:2
verses.text: LXV.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:3
verses.text: —Precepts About Those Things Which are Commanded, and of Pity.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:4
verses.text: I have spoken of those things which are forbidden; I will now briefly say what things are commanded.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:5
verses.text: Closely connected with harmlessness is pity.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:6
verses.text: For the former does not inflict injury, the latter works good; the former begins justice, the latter completes it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:7
verses.text: For since the nature of men is more feeble than that of the other animals, which God has provided with means of inflicting violence, and with defences for repelling it, He has given to us the affection of pity, that we might place the whole protection of our life in mutual aid.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:8
verses.text: For if we are created by one God, and descended from one man, and are thus connected by the law of consanguinity, we ought on this account to love every man; and therefore we are bound not only to abstain from the infliction of injury, but not even to avenge it when inflicted on us, that there may be in us complete harmlessness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:9
verses.text: And on this account God commands us to pray always even for our enemies.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:10
verses.text: Therefore we ought to be an animal fitted for companionship and society, that we may mutually protect ourselves by giving and receiving assistance.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:11
verses.text: For our frailty is liable to many accidents and inconveniences.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:12
verses.text: Expect that that which you see has happened to another may happen to you also.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:13
verses.text: Thus you will at length be excited to render aid, if you shall assume the mind of him who, being placed in evils, implores your aid.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:14
verses.text: If any one is in need of food, let us bestow it; if any one meets us who is naked, let us clothe him; if any one suffers injury from one who is more powerful than himself, let us rescue him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:15
verses.text: Let our house be open to strangers, or to those who are in need of shelter.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:16
verses.text: Let our defence not be wanting to wards, or our protection to the defenceless.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:17
verses.text: To ransom captives is a great work of pity, and also to visit and comfort the sick who are in poverty.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:18
verses.text: If the helpless or strangers die, we should not permit them to lie unburied.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:19
verses.text: These are the works, these the duties, of pity; and if any one undertakes these, he will offer unto God a true and acceptable sacrifice.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:20
verses.text: This victim is more adapted for an offering to God, who is not appeased with the blood of a sheep, but with the piety of man, whom God, because He is just, follows up with His own law, and with His own condition.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:21
verses.text: He shows mercy to him whom He sees to be merciful; He is inexorable to him whom He sees to be harsh to those who entreat him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 61:22
verses.text: Therefore, that we may be able to do all these things, which are pleasing to God, money is to be despised, and to be transferred to heavenly treasures, where neither thief can break through, nor rust corrupt, nor tyrant take away, but it may be preserved for us under the guardianship of God to our eternal wealth.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:2
verses.text: LXVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:3
verses.text: —Of Faith in Religion, and of Fortitude.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:4
verses.text: Faith also is a great part of justice; and this ought especially to be preserved by us, who bear the name of faith, especially in religion, because God is before and to be preferred to man.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:5
verses.text: And if it is a glorious thing to undergo death in behalf of friends, of parents, and of children, that is, in behalf of man, and if he who has done this obtains lasting memory and praise, how much more so in behalf of God, who is able to bestow eternal life in return for temporal death? Therefore, when a necessity of this kind happens, that we are compelled to turn aside from God, and to pass over to the rites of the heathens, no fear, no terror should turn us aside from guarding the faith delivered to us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:6
verses.text: Let God be before our eyes, in our heart, by whose inward help we may overcome the pain of our flesh, and the torments applied to our body.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:7
verses.text: Then let us think of nothing else but the rewards of an immortal life.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:8
verses.text: And thus, even though our limbs should be torn in pieces, or burnt, we shall easily endure all things which the madness of tyrannical cruelty shall contrive against us.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:9
verses.text: Lastly, let us strive to undergo death itself, not unwillingly or timidly, but willingly and undauntedly, as those who know what glory we are about to have in the presence of God, having triumphed over the world and coming to the things promised us; with what good things and how great blessedness we shall be compensated for these brief evils of punishments, and the injuries of this life.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:10
verses.text: But if the opportunity of this glory shall be wanting, faith will have its reward even in peace.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:11
verses.text: Therefore let it be observed in all the duties of life, let it be observed in marriage.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:12
verses.text: For it is not sufficient if you abstain from another's bed, or from the brothel.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:13
verses.text: Let him who has a wife seek nothing further, but, content with her alone, let him guard the mysteries of the marriage-bed chaste and undefiled.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:14
verses.text: For he is equally an adulterer in the sight of God and impure, who, having thrown off the yoke, wantons in strange pleasure either with a free woman or a slave.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:15
verses.text: But as a woman is bound by the bonds of chastity not to desire any other man, so let the husband be bound by the same law, since God has joined together the husband and the wife in the union of one body.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:16
verses.text: On this account He has commanded that the wife shall not be put away unless convicted of adultery, and that the bond of the conjugal compact shall never be dissolved, unless unfaithfulness have broken it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:17
verses.text: This also is added for the completion of chastity, that there should be an absence not only of the offence, but even of the thought.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:18
verses.text: For it is evident that the mind is polluted by the desire, though unaccomplished; and so that a just man ought neither to do, nor to wish to do, that which is unjust.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:19
verses.text: Therefore the conscience must be cleansed; for God, who cannot be deceived, inspects it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 62:20
verses.text: The breast must be cleared from every stain, that it may be a temple of God, which is enlightened not by the gleam of gold or ivory, but by the brightness of faith and purity.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:2
verses.text: LXVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:3
verses.text: —Of Repentance, the Immortality of the Soul, and of Providence.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:4
verses.text: But it is true all these things are difficult to man, nor does the condition of his frailty permit that any one should be without blemish.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:5
verses.text: Therefore the last remedy is this, that we have recourse to repentance, which has not the least place among the virtues, because it is a correction of oneself; that when we have happened to fail either in deed or in word, we may immediately come to a better mind, and confess that we have offended, and entreat pardon from God, which according to His mercy He will not deny, except to those who persist in their error.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:6
verses.text: Great is the aid, great the solace of repentance.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:7
verses.text: That is the healing of wounds and offences, that hope, that the harbour of safety; and he who takes away this cuts off from himself the way of salvation, because no one can be so just that repentance is never necessary for him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:8
verses.text: But we, even though there is no offence of ours, yet ought to confess to God, and to entreat pardon for our faults, and to give thanks even in evils.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:9
verses.text: Let us always offer this obedience to our Lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:10
verses.text: For humility is dear and lovely in the sight of God; for since He rather receives the sinner who confesses his fault, than the just man who is haughty, how much more will He receive the just man who confesses, and exalt him in His heavenly kingdom in proportion to his humility! These are the things which the worshipper of God ought to hold forth; these are the victims, this the sacrifice, which is acceptable; this is true worship, when a man offers upon the altar of God the pledges of his own mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:11
verses.text: That supreme Majesty rejoices in such a worshipper as this, as it takes him as a son and bestows upon him the befitting reward of immortality, concerning which I must now speak, and refute the persuasion of those who think that the soul is destroyed together with the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:12
verses.text: For inasmuch as they neither knew God nor were able to perceive the mystery of the world, they did not even comprehend the nature of man and of the soul.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:13
verses.text: For how could they see the consequences, who did not hold the main point? Therefore, in denying the existence of a providence, they plainly denied the existence of God, who is the fountain and source of all things.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:14
verses.text: It followed that they should either affirm that those things which exist have always existed, or were produced of their own accord, or arose from a meeting together of minute seeds.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:15
verses.text: It cannot be said that that which exists, and is visible, always existed; for it cannot exist of itself without some beginning.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:16
verses.text: But nothing can be produced of its own accord, because there is no nature without one who generates it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:17
verses.text: But how could there be original seeds, since both the seeds arise from objects, and, in their turn, objects from seeds? Therefore there is no seed which has not origin.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:18
verses.text: Thus it came to pass, that when they supposed that the world was produced by no providence, they did not suppose that even man was produced by any plan.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:19
verses.text: But if no plan was made use of in the creation of man, therefore the soul cannot be immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:20
verses.text: But others, on the other hand, thought there was but one God, and that the world was made by Him, and made for the sake of men, and that souls are immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:21
verses.text: But though they entertained true sentiments, nevertheless they did not perceive the causes, or reasons, or issues of this divine work and design, so as to complete the whole mystery of the truth, and to comprise it within some limit.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 63:22
verses.text: But that which they were not able to do, because they did not hold the truth in its integrity, must be done by us, who know it on the announcement of God.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:2
verses.text: LXVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:3
verses.text: —Of the World, Man, and the Providence of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:4
verses.text: Let us therefore consider what was the plan of making this so great and so immense a work.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:5
verses.text: God made the world, as Plato thought, but he does not show why He made it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:6
verses.text: Because He is good, he says, and envying no one, He made the things which are good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:7
verses.text: But we see that there are both good and evil things in the system of nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:8
verses.text: Some perverse person may stand forth, such as that atheist Theodorus was, and answer Plato: Nay, because He is evil, He made the things which are evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:9
verses.text: How will he refute him? If God made the things which are good, whence have such great evils burst forth, which, for the most part, even prevail over those which are good? They were contained, he says, in the matter.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:10
verses.text: If there were evil, therefore there were also good things; so that either God made nothing, or if He made only good things, the evil things which were not made are more eternal than the good things which had a beginning.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:11
verses.text: Therefore the things which at one time began will have an end, and those which always existed will be permanent.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:12
verses.text: Therefore evils are preferable.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:13
verses.text: But if they cannot be preferable, they cannot indeed be more eternal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:14
verses.text: Therefore they either always existed, and God has been inactive, or they both flowed from one source.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:15
verses.text: For it is more in accordance with reason that God made all things, than that He made nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:16
verses.text: Therefore, according to the sentiments of Plato, the same God is both good, because He made good things, and evil, because He made evil things.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:17
verses.text: And if this cannot be so, it is evident that the world was not made by God on this account, because He is good.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:18
verses.text: For He comprised all things, both good and evil; nor did He make anything for its own sake, but on account of something else.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:19
verses.text: A house is built not for this purpose only, that there may be a house, but that it may receive and shelter an inhabitant.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:20
verses.text: Likewise a ship is built not for this purpose, that it may appear only to be a ship, but that men may be able to sail in it.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:21
verses.text: Vessels also are made, not only that the vessels may exist, but that they may receive things which are necessary for use.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:22
verses.text: Thus also God must have made the world for some use.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:23
verses.text: The Stoics say that it was made for the sake of men; and rightly so.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:24
verses.text: For men enjoy all these good things which the world contains in itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:25
verses.text: But they do not explain why men themselves were made, or what advantage Providence, the Maker of all things, has in them.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:26
verses.text: Plato also affirms that souls are immortal, but why, or in what manner, or at what time, or by whose instrumentality they attain to immortality, or what is the nature of that great mystery, why those who are about to become immortal are previously born mortal, and then, having completed the course of their temporal life, and having laid aside the covering of their frail bodies, are transferred to that eternal blessedness,—of all this he has no comprehension.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:27
verses.text: Finally, he did not explain the judgment of God, nor the distinction between the just and the unjust, but supposed that the souls which have plunged themselves into crimes are condemned thus far, that they may be reproduced in the lower animals, and thus atone for their offences, until they again return to the forms of men, and that this is always taking place, and that there is no end of this transmigration.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 64:28
verses.text: In my opinion, he introduces some sport resembling a dream, in which there appears to be neither plan, nor government of God, nor any design.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:2
verses.text: LXIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:3
verses.text: —That the World Was Made on Account of Man, and Man on Account of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:4
verses.text: I will now say what is that chief point which not even those who spoke the truth were able to connect together, bringing into one view causes and reasons.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:5
verses.text: The world was made by God, that men might be born; again, men are born, that they may acknowledge God as a Father, in whom is wisdom; they acknowledge Him, that they may worship Him, in whom is justice; they worship Him, that they may receive the reward of immortality; they receive immortality, that they may serve God for ever.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:6
verses.text: Do you see how closely connected the first are with the middle, and the middle with the last? Let us look into them separately, and see whether they are consistent with each other.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:7
verses.text: God made the world on account of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:8
verses.text: He who does not see this, does not differ much from a beast.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:9
verses.text: Who but man looks up to the heaven? who views with admiration the sun, who the stars, who all the works of God? Who inhabits the earth? who receives the fruit from it? Who has in his power the fishes, who the winged creatures, who the quadrupeds, except man? Therefore God made all things on account of man, because all things have turned out for the use of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:10
verses.text: The philosophers saw this, but they did not see the consequence, that He made man himself on His own account.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:11
verses.text: For it was befitting, and pious, and necessary, that since He contrived such great works for the sake of man, when He gave him so much honour, and so much power, that he should bear rule in the world, man should both acknowledge God, the Author of such great benefits, who made the world itself on his account, and should pay Him the worship and honour due to Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:12
verses.text: Here Plato erred; here he lost the truth which he had at first laid hold of, when he was silent concerning the worship of that God whom he confessed to be the framer and parent of all things, and did not understand that man is bound to God by the ties of piety, whence religion itself receives its name, and that this is the only thing on account of which souls become immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:13
verses.text: He perceived, however, that they are eternal, but he did not descend by the regular gradations to that opinion.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:14
verses.text: For the middle arguments being taken away, he rather fell into the truth, as though by some abrupt precipice; nor did he advance further, since he had found the truth by accident, and not by reason.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 65:15
verses.text: Therefore God is to be worshipped, that by means of religion, which is also justice, man may receive from God immortality, nor is there any other reward of a pious mind; and if this is invisible, it cannot be presented by the invisible God with any reward but that which is invisible.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:2
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:3
verses.text: —The Immortality of the Soul is Confirmed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:4
verses.text: It may in truth be collected from many arguments that souls are eternal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:5
verses.text: Plato says that that which always moves by itself, and has no beginning of motion, also has no end; but that the soul of man always moves by itself, and because it is flexible for reflection, subtle for discovery, easy of perception, adapted to learning, and because it retains the past, comprehends the present, foresees the future, and embraces the knowledge of many subjects and arts, that it is immortal, since it contains nothing which is mixed with the contagion of earthly weight.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:6
verses.text: Moreover, the eternity of the soul is understood from virtue and pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:7
verses.text: Pleasure is common to all animals, virtue belongs only to man; the former is vicious, the latter is honourable; the former is in accordance with nature, the latter is opposed to nature, unless the soul is immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:8
verses.text: For in defence of faith and justice, virtue neither fears want, nor is alarmed at exile, nor dreads imprisonment, nor shrinks from pain, nor refuses death; and because these things are contrary to nature, either virtue is foolishness, if it stands in the way of advantages, and is injurious to life; or if it is not foolishness, then the soul is immortal, and despises present goods, because other things are preferable which it attains after the dissolution of the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:9
verses.text: But that is the greatest proof of immortality, that man alone has the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:10
verses.text: In the dumb animals there is no notion of religion, because they are earthly and bent down to the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:11
verses.text: Man is upright, and beholds the heaven for this purpose, that he may seek God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:12
verses.text: Therefore he cannot be other than immortal, who longs for the immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:13
verses.text: He cannot be liable to dissolution, who is connected with God both in countenance and mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:14
verses.text: Finally, man alone makes use of the heavenly element, which is fire.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:15
verses.text: For if light is through fire, and life through light, it is evident that he who has the use of fire is not mortal, since this is closely connected, this is intimately related to Him without whom neither light nor life can exist.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:16
verses.text: But why do we infer from arguments that souls are eternal, when we have divine testimonies? For the sacred writings and the voices of the prophets teach this.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:17
verses.text: And if this appears to any one insufficient, let him read the poems of the Sibyls, let him also weigh the answers of the Milesian Apollo, that he may understand that Democritus, and Epicurus, and Dicaearchus raved, who alone of all mortals denied that which is evident.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:18
verses.text: Having proved the immortality of the soul, it remains to teach by whom, and to whom, and in what manner, and at what time, it is given.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:19
verses.text: Since fixed and divinely appointed times have begun to be filled up, a destruction and consummation of all things must of necessity take place, that the world may be renewed by God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:20
verses.text: But that time is at hand, as far as may be collected from the number of years, and from the signs which are foretold by the prophets.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:21
verses.text: But since the things which have been spoken concerning the end of the world and the conclusion of the times are innumerable, those very things which are spoken are to be laid down without adornment, since it would be a boundless task to bring forward the testimonies.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:22
verses.text: If any one wishes for them, or does not place full confidence in us, let him approach to the very shrine of the heavenly letters, and being more fully instructed through their trustworthiness, let him perceive that the philosophers have erred, who thought either that this world was eternal, or that there would be numberless thousands of years from the time when it was prepared.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:23
verses.text: For six thousand years have not yet been completed, and when this number shall be made up, then at length all evil will be taken away, that justice alone may reign.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 66:24
verses.text: And how this will come to pass, I will explain in few words.

chapters.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:2
verses.text: LXXI.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:3
verses.text: —Of the Last Times.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:4
verses.text: These things are said by the prophets, but as seers, to be about to happen.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:5
verses.text: When the last end shall begin to approach to the world, wickedness will increase; all kinds of vices and frauds will become frequent; justice will perish; faith, peace, mercy, modesty, truth, will have no existence; violence and daring will abound; no one will have anything, unless it is acquired by the hand, and defended by the hand.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:6
verses.text: If there shall be any good men, they will be esteemed as a prey and a laughing-stock.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:7
verses.text: No one will exhibit filial affection to parents, no one will pity an infant or an old man; avarice and lust will corrupt all things.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:8
verses.text: There will be slaughter and bloodshed.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:9
verses.text: There will be wars, and those not only between foreign and neighbouring states, but also intestine wars.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:10
verses.text: States will carry on wars among themselves, every sex and age will handle arms.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:11
verses.text: The dignity of government will not be preserved, nor military discipline; but after the manner of robbery, there will be depredation and devastation.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:12
verses.text: Kingly power will be multiplied, and ten men will occupy, portion out, and devour the world.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:13
verses.text: There will arise another by far more powerful and wicked, who, having destroyed three, will obtain Asia, and having reduced and subdued the others under his own power, will harass all the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:14
verses.text: He will appoint new laws, abrogate old ones; he will make the state his own, and will change the name and seat of the government.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:15
verses.text: Then there will be a dreadful and detestable time, in which no one would choose to live.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:16
verses.text: In fine, such will be the condition of things, that lamentation will follow the living, and congratulation the dead.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:17
verses.text: Cities and towns will be destroyed, at one time by fire and the sword, at another by repeated earthquakes; now by inundation of waters, now by pestilence and famine.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:18
verses.text: The earth will produce nothing, being barren either through excessive cold or heat.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:19
verses.text: All water will be partly changed into blood, partly vitiated by bitterness, so that none of it can be useful for food, or wholesome for drinking.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:20
verses.text: To these evils will also be added prodigies from heaven, that nothing may be wanting to men for causing fear.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:21
verses.text: Comets will frequently appear.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:22
verses.text: The sun will be overshadowed with perpetual paleness.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:23
verses.text: The moon will be stained with blood, nor will it repair the losses of its light taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:24
verses.text: All the stars will fall, nor will the seasons preserve their regularity, winter and summer being confused.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:25
verses.text: Then both the year, and the month, and the day will be shortened.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:26
verses.text: And Trismegistus has declared that this is the old age and decline of the world.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:27
verses.text: And when this shall have come, it must be known that the time is at hand in which God will return to change the world.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:28
verses.text: But in the midst of these evils there will arise an impious king, hostile not only to mankind, but also to God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:29
verses.text: He will trample upon, torment, harass and put to death those who have been spared by that former tyrant.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:30
verses.text: Then there will be ever-flowing tears, perpetual wailings and lamentations, and useless prayers to God; there will be no rest from fear, no sleep for a respite.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:31
verses.text: The day will always increase disaster, the night alarm.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:32
verses.text: Thus the world will be reduced almost to solitude, certainly to fewness of men.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:33
verses.text: Then also the impious man will persecute the just and those who are dedicated to God, and will give orders that he himself shall be worshipped as God.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:34
verses.text: For he will say that he is Christ, though he will be His adversary.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:35
verses.text: That he may be believed, he will receive the power of doing wonders, so that fire may descend from heaven, the sun retire from his course, and the image which he shall have set up may speak.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:36
verses.text: And by these prodigies he shall entice many to worship him, and to receive his sign in their hand or forehead.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:37
verses.text: And he who shall not worship him and receive his sign will die with refined tortures.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:38
verses.text: Thus he will destroy nearly two parts, the third will flee into desolate solitudes.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:39
verses.text: But he, frantic and raging with implacable anger, will lead an army and besiege the mountain to which the righteous shall have fled.

verses.name: Lactantius: The Epitome of the Divine Institutes 67:40
verses.text: And when they shall see themselves besieged, they will implore the aid of God with a loud voice, and God shall hear them, and shall send to them a deliverer.
